awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Deep Learning for Solar Energy Systems to Optimize Whole System Performance
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide secure and high-performance solar energy to reduce pollution and energy cost, and help establish self-sustainable micogrids.  As the proposed new deep learning-based controller taps into both hardware and software sub-segments for microgrids, the commercial opportunity is considerable. The proposed technology has the potential provide a large-scale microgrid system with affordable off-grid capability and establish a reliable microgrid system with cyberprotection. It offers a cost-effective energy solution to homeowners, schools, business owners, hospitals and clinics, military facilities and other organizations with significant power demands.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a new microgrid controller integrated with a deep neural network algorithm to optimize the system performance with both output and security. The model will help redesign photovoltaic (PV) filters, boost converters and micro-inverters by setting different parameters. Comparing with a simulation-based model, the deep neural network algorithm has a 15% margin on prediction accuracy and speeds up the response time from minute-level to millisecond-level. As a result, 4700 kWh of electricity can be saved annually for a 2000 sq ft house in a state with 80%  sunny days. Due to the millions of parameters used in the algorithm, the new controller is able to support hundreds of users in a single grid. The core of the proposed project includes two deep neural networks (DNNs) using internet of things (IoT)-based sensors for the microgrid data processing. By leveraging the deep learning model and IoT sensors, the proposed system can monitor and detect abnormal usage pattern for the entire system in real time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our I-Corps team is an interdisciplinary collaborative effort between researchers in engineering, and business management. The goal of this grant is to understand microgrid customers and develop value propositions for the green energy market.  The Broader Impact of this grant addressed energy cost which is a major public burden.  The cost of a microgrid controller in general is $35000 for initial installment for all software and hardware. And a $6500 annually subscription fee is applied for updates. To project the total saving amount of our controller, we assume that our controller is applied in a middle-size community with 500 households. Comparing with current controller, our new controller can save the community $200000 annually. In order to be more competitive, we propose $30000 for initial installment for our new controller with a $6000 subscription fee,
Funded by NSF I-Corps, the intellectual merit of this effort includes  a new microgrid controller integrated with deep neural network algorithm to optimize the system performance with both output and security. The model will help redesign PV filters, boost converters and micro inverters by setting different parameters. Due to the millions of parameters used in our algorithm, the new controller is able to support hundreds of users in a single grid. By leveraging the deep learning model and IoT technologies, our system can monitor and detect abnormal usage pattern for the entire system in real-time. The core of this innovation is the deep neural network that provide accurate prediction and real-time response speed.
Outcomes in customer identifications: 1) CEOs of Companies who are owners of facilities in remote area that isolated with main utility grids and need power connection; 2) CEOs of agricultural companies, such as green houses, that purchase electricity to power the lighting andclimate control; 3) CEOs of companies who are owners of infrastructures which consumes large amount of electricity such as shopping malls, hospitals, and other large scale buildings. 
Outcomes in the trainings: The team has worked with Bio Sphere II and Tech Launch Arizona to continue training and educations for students and other outreach groups in the green energy communities. The team has developed training materials and courses in leadership development in Innovation and Entrepreneurship and have delivered presentations to native American tribes and local Hispanic Communities. 


Last Modified: 06/14/2022
Modified by: Janet M Roveda
